Introduction

The total or partial evacuation of a hospital will normally only be enacted as a last resort when the lives and safety of the staff, patients and visitors are at risk. The decision to evacuate a hospital would be taken jointly by the Trust Executive/Strategic (Gold) Commander, in hours this will be through the Site leadership Team (SLT), out of hours the On Call Director, on-call Senior Manager on Call (SMOC) /Tactical (Silver) Commander and Clinical site Coordinators, in conjunction with other multi-agency partners. The whole-site evacuation of a hospital site will be deemed a Major Incident and must be reported accordingly.

Traditionally hospital evacuation procedures rely on horizontal evacuation for clinical / bedded patient departments / wards and the progression to vertical evacuation if a fire or other incident requires further separation, and if necessary evacuation outside of the building.

NHS organisations owe a duty of care to both their patients and their staff and therefore healthcare providers should be aware and understand that it is not the responsibility of the emergency services to decide to evacuate an NHS facility; this responsibility rests with the organisation under whose care the patient(s) are under

The plan assumes that a Critical / Major Incident will be declared and the usual responses to the declaration of a Critical / Major Incident have been instigated (Please see Major Incident Plan MSEPO-21147).
An evacuation should only be carried out if the benefit of leaving an area significantly outweighs the risk of sheltering in place.

The over-riding priority must be the safety of the patient(s), staff, contractors and the public. Evacuation should not be assumed to be the best option for all risks, and may not be the safest. Buildings offer significant protection against most risks and immediate shelter may be safer at least initially.
This policy refers to the Emergency Planning and Business Continuity Policies / Plans of Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) to ensure a combined approach to Resilience functions.

It is the responsibility of Directors and Managers to ensure that they and their teams are aware and understand their roles and responsibilities in the event of a business disruption and/or emergency situation. All MSE staff should be aware of this policy.
Possible scenarios that could render evacuation necessary are:
Severe fire, where normal horizontal evacuation plans are no longer viable.
Severe flood, where normal horizontal plans are no longer viable;
Hazardous materials (HazMat) Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear and Explosive (CBRNe) incidents, where the contamination is not contained within one area;
Conventional terrorist incidents i.e. explosions / bomb threats; suspect packages
Catastrophic and prolonged utility failure;
Major threat of any of the above;

While horizontal evacuation may be appropriate in response to a fire, other potential scenarios may require the evacuation of the whole building or even the entire hospital site, depending on the situation and its potential risk to patients, staff and visitors.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

Provide a Trust wide framework for responding to an emergency situation which requires the Trust to implement evacuation and sheltering procedures; either full or partial, and how this will be achieved through establishing clear command, control and communication procedures, to ensure the safe evacuation of staff, patients, contractors and visitors.
Implement evacuation procedures, either partial or full

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust

Emergency Preparedness, Resilience Response Committee is to ensure that the Trust has business continuity and emergency plans in place, and robust business continuity and emergency preparedness, resilience and response management system, validate plans and policies in line with national standards.
Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust has in place effective arrangements to respond to an incident that has the potential to affect service provision.

Deputy Chief Executive (Accountable Emergency Officer) takes responsibility for Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response on behalf of the organisation. This includes ensuring that the Trust is properly prepared and resourced for dealing with an incident
Directors and Senior Managers are responsible for ensuring that:
Business Continuity plans are developed and in place for their areas and functions of responsibility.
Business Continuity plans are cascaded to staff who are given appropriate training.
Plans are tested and reviewed annually or sooner as appropriate.
Head of Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response (EPRR) will work with the Accountable Emergency Officer to ensure the following actions are in place;
The Trust's process for adverse weather planning and Business Continuity is understood and followed
Plans and guidance is distributed to Directors, Departmental and Service Leads and Heads of Nursing.
Distribute Met Office Weather alerts as they are received in order that appropriate actions according to plans can be taken.
Clinical Service Leads / Service Managers are responsible for implementing this document in the Clinical Service areas and for monitoring the impact on the service.
Senior Sisters / Nursing Staff

The Senior Sister/nurse in charge is accountable for the safe care and management of patient on the ward. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff within the ward complies with this document.
Head of Estates and Facilities is responsible for:
The gritting of traffic access routes, car parking areas and pedestrian walking on site premises.
Identifying any potential issues relating to period of severe weather (including snow and ice) and ensuring appropriate actions taken to reduce risk.
Implement business continuity plans as appropriate
Ensuring that the Trust's fire detection / alarm system conforms to current standards
Fire Officer is responsible for ensuring that the Trust, has in place a suitable programme of education, and for undertaking risk assessments.
Staff must make themselves familiar with their individual roles as set out in:
This plans procedures and actions described.
Individual's services / departmental Business Continuity plans.
Evacuation
Evacuation and shelter

5.1.1 When evacuation has become necessary, it is generally undertaken in stages, progressive horizontal evacuation is a tried and tested process, this involves moving people in immediate risk to a place of temporary safety beyond the nearest fire compartment wall. From here further evacuation can take place should it become necessary.

5.1.2 The need for shelter or evacuation will depend on the circumstances of the incident. The type of incident will also influence the time available for evacuation and whether a full or partial evacuation is required
5.1.3 For health and social care providers there are three primary levels when evacuation may be necessary or should be considered:

table_items.text: No immediate threat to life or safety, but there is an incident on an adjoining floor or an adjacent building (advanced warning provided)
A situation with no immediate threat, but one where the incident is likely to spread, or be prolonged so as to affect patient care in that area, from an adjoining area (advanced warning provided)
The situation where there is an immediate threat to life or safety (no advanced warning provided)

data.text: 5.1.4 Evacuation and shelter arrangements must be flexible to allow the response to be tailored to the incident, planning for such events must be undertaken in conjunction with a number of other existing arrangements including:
Command and control
Major incident plans
Mass Casualty Plan
Fire Response Plan
Business Continuity arrangements
Lockdown plans
Mutual aid

5.1.5 It should be remembered that NHS-funded organisations are responsible for the decision to evacuate their facilities, not the emergency services, and will remain responsible for evacuated patients and for the continued delivery of care and treatment –whether in a healthcare facility or not – until those patients are formally discharged.

5.1.6 The decision to evacuate from an acute care setting would be taken at a Strategic level with Operational input; however the decision to evacuate an area may need to be taken immediately, in these circumstances the Clinical Site team will carry out a dynamic risk assessment and make the decision if evacuate should occur and to what extent.
Partial evacuation

Partial evacuation involves moving away from the area of danger to a safe place within the same building, taking account of known potential hazards including the buildings structural integrity. This can be achieved by evacuating:

‘Horizontally' to an area on the same floor. If fire is the cause of the evacuation, movement should be to the next fire compartment sections on that floor i.e. moving through two hours of fire protection as a minimum, usually through two one hour fire doors.
‘Vertically' two floors below the area of danger, if achievable.
Full evacuation
The total evacuation of a provider site, including all the buildings on it.
Off-site evacuation

Evacuation to an off-site location to provide an area of safety away from the affected site, which may be a holding location until patients are either redirected to another healthcare setting or are taken home.
Slow time evacuation
This is where the need to evacuate is known and there is time for this to happen in an ordered manner. This allows more time for an organised evacuation.

It should be noted that as an incident develops it may be necessary to move from a slow paced evacuation to move to a faster paced evacuation, depending upon the information being received by the Incident Control Centre.
Fast time
This where there is a need to initiate evacuation at a fast pace, either due to a sudden incident the severity of the incident or to maintain Patient, staff and visitor safety.
Decision to evacuate

The decision to evacuate a hospital would be taken jointly by the Trust Executive/Strategic (Gold) Commander in hours this will be through the Site leadership Team (SLT), out of hours the On Call Director, on-call Senior Manager on Call (SMOC) /Tactical (Silver) Commander and Clinical site Coordinators, in conjunction with other multi-agency partners. The whole-site evacuation of a hospital site will be deemed a Major Incident and must be reported accordingly.

However the decision to evacuate an area may need to be taken immediately, in these circumstances the Clinical Site Coordinator will carry out a dynamic risk assessment and make the decision to evacuate and to what extent.
Raising the alarm
The alarm should be raised using standard Trust procedures
By activating the nearest red break glass fire call point
By dialling the emergency number and informing switchboard of the emergency and the location.
Hospital zoning and muster points
Hospital zoning

Hospital zoning is a system that allows a hospital to be divided into naturally occurring sections, in order to ascertain what is contained within an individual zone, and aid the evacuation process by controlling the evacuation to specific areas. Patients and staff can also be assembled at pre-designated muster points out side of the building if required
Please see MSE Trust Fire Safety Policy, MSE Trust Fire Safety Protocol, and site specific Fire Safety Emergency Response Procedures
Muster points
Pre-designated muster points are identified in the Trust Fire Plans; they make it easier for emergency services to bring specific resources on to site.
Traffic management

During a full scale evacuation it is vital to ensure easy access and exit to the site by emergency services, so it may be necessary to control staff and visitors leaving the site by car, in order to ensure that the access roads remain accessible by emergency vehicles.
This will be achieved through liaison with the Police and local security staff, in liaison with the Incident Control Centre.
Lockdown
Lockdown policy and procedure refer to Lockdown policy; reference number MSEPO 21146
Communications
Internal communications

In all incidents, effective communications are paramount, it should be recognised that the use of the normal channels of communications may not be available in an evacuation situation. In such a situation, local information cascade plans and procedures should be adopted.
Two way radios
The Trust has two way radio systems on each site, which are available during incidents and are located in the following locations:
Southend
Command and Control radios, designated call sign Hotel which consist of 30 radios located in the Clinical Site Office first floor Nerve Centre
Ward and department radios, designated call sign Switchboard and will be distributed by Switchboard and consists of 40 radios
Basildon
A total of 12 command and control radios are located in the following locations:
6 radios are located within the Control Centre, Clinical Site managers Office (C007) on Level C, Jubilee Wing
Radios are held in the Car Parking Office on level B.
A number of walkie-talkie radios are also available for use via the Head of EPRR
Broomfield
A total of 24 Command and control radios are situated in the Switchboard, located on the ground floor main reception area
Patient tracking
Patient tracking management

All patients must be tracked during evacuation, whilst it is recognised that the Trust has patient record management systems, patient records should, where possible, go with the patient. In some cases, it may not be possible to take a full set of patient's notes with an evacuated patient and in that case, it would be realistic to only take the most relevant and most recent notes that relate to the patients current episode of care.
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.

Appendix 1: Healthcare evacuation triage priorities

table_items.text: EP1 These patients require minimal assistance and can be moved FIRST. Patients are ambulatory, and 1 member of staff can safely lead severely patients to the External Triage Area

Patients can get out and dress in adequate clothing with no or minimal assistance AND mobiles independently, whether walking or by wheelchair, at the same pace and for the same distance as a member of staff.
P3 These patients can safely be moved LAST from the temporary shelter locations to another healthcare facility / reception centre or be discharged home.

EP2 These patients require some assistance and should be SECOND in priority. Patients may require wheelchair, assistance in walking or bed bound but require 1 – 2 members of staff to aid transportation

Examples might include: a) Patients can only be moved on his / her bed b) Patient is connected to 1 piece of apparatus (e.g. drainage bag) c) Patient must be moved in a wheelchair by another person d) Patient requires more than minimal assistance or is unwilling to be dressed in adequate clothing requiring therefore 1 or more persons to assist e) Patient cannot be left without supervision f) Patients can walk unaided for less than 5 meters
P2 These patients will be moved SECOND in priority as transfers to another hospital

EP3 These patients require maximum assistance to move. In an evacuation, these patients move LAST. These patients may require 2-4 members of staff to evacuate (e.g. bedbound attached to equipment or on-going high care needs)

Examples might include: a) Patients is on assisted ventilation b) Patient requires the assistance of 2 or more staff to effect evacuation c) Patient cannot be disconnected from 1 or more pieces of apparatus for more than 60 seconds d) Patient is connected to life support machinery e) Patient is unconscious and / or in life threatening state f) Patient requires more than 7 minutes to be disconnected from 1 piece of equipment g) Patient is undergoing surgery h) Patient has undergone major surgery under general anaesthetic i) Patient can only be moved on his / her bed AND requires 2 or more staff to effect evacuation j) Patient is in critical condition / attached to more than 1 piece of apparatus k) Patient requires one-to-one supervision
P1 These patients require maximum support to sustain life. These patients move FIRST once stable from the hospital holding area to another hospital

data.text: Appendix 13: Local authority shelter locations
Local Authority assistance Shelters/Rest Centres and Transport
In  the  event  of  the  hospital  needing  to externally  evacuate, local  authorities  at Basildon and Thurrock have a number of Rest Centres identified that they can utilise to shelter evacuees.
Contacting the Local Authorities at the earliest opportunity (even to just put them on standby) is essential to ensure a quick set up of these facilities.

The Local Authority will as part of the set up arrangement will allocate a Rest Centre manager that will work alongside the Hospital staff to look after the evacuees. A team will be provided to facilitate and maintain the rest centre.
In order to meet any medical needs of the evacuees, the Trust will need to supply some suitably trained staff to attend the centres.
Notification/ Requests for Shelters/ Rest Centres

In order for the Local Authorities to respond in a timely fashion, the Trust needs to contact the key point of contact, Essex County Council Emergency Planning and Resilience Team (EPR Team) available 24/7. The On call duty officer will cascade to the Local Borough on call Duty Emergency Planning Officer (DEPO),
Thought should be given to the two Unitary Authorities (Southend and Thurrock) who also have a 24/7 on call DEPO in case they are not included in the cascade by the EPR team

Once contacted the local DEPO's involved will contact the Hospital Control Centre to advise which of the Rest Centres will be available for use. This will be subject to a dynamic Risk Assessment including the following as part of that assessment:-
Numbers involved for the evacuation
Type of facilities required (e.g. disabled access, etc.)
Availability of facility at time of the incident (e.g. School during school hours may not be suitable; existing events or functions taking place at venues available etc.)
The Local Authority also has a number of emergency contacts to arrange emergency transportation for those being evacuated to the Rest Centre/Shelters.
It should also be noted that transportation may be limited in the early stages of the incident, again an early request will reduce this limited availability time.
Liaison with Control Centre

On being notified the DEPO will despatch a Local Authority Liaison Officer (LALO) to attend, the identified Incident Control Centre location, to act as a liaison for the Rest Centres/Shelters and any available local authority supplied Transport needs.

On  arrival all further  requests  will  be  directed  through  the  LALO  for  any  Local Authority requirements. Depend on the situation and availability of resources, this can be done through virtual process through Local Authority Single Point of Contact.
